bibl.title: Letter from Pride Thomas to Howard A. Kelly, March 6, 1905

div1.p: Thomas writes about a yellow fever epidemic in Wilmington, North Carolina, in 1862.

div1.head: Letter from Pride Thomas to Howard A. Kelly, March 6, 1905
div1.opener:
3/10/05
will return Journal
DR. PRIDE JONES THOMAS,
WILMINGTON, N. C.
March 6th, 1905.pb
Journal returned & ack.
July 8/05. Thien.
Dr. Howard A. Kelly,
Baltimore, Md.
Dear Doctor:-
div1.p:
I am told you are looking up the records of the outbreak of
yellow fever in this place, Wilmington, N. C.

I beg leave to say I have what was considered a complete history
of the outbreak of the yellow fever in 1862, written by my grand-father,
the late Dr. William George Thomas. It is proper to say, in this con-
nection, that he was at that time actively engaged in the practice of
medicine in Wilmington, and was here from the date of the arrival of
the blockade runner “Kate”, August 6th, 1862, until he was strickened
with the fever in the first week of October. You will pardon me for
saying he was at that time, and up to the time of his death, in 1890,
the leading practitioner of Wilmington. You will note, if you should
desire to read this article, that it is written to disprove the asser-
tion of Dr. W. T. Wragg of Charleston, S. C., that the whole trouble in the
Southern States was of spontaneous origin. Dr. Wragg was a highly es-
teemed physician of his native city, and had participated in the care
of those sick with the disease in Charleston in quite a number of seri-
ous outbreaks. The excellent work of the lamented Walter Reed, which
established the fact that the conveyance of yellow fever poison was by
means of the stegomyia fasciata, was then not dreamed of. Following the
suggestion along this line, made by Dr. Carlos Finlay in the 80s, you
will note that among the first cases recorded were persons who visited
the steamer “Kate” or lived so short a distance from the wharf at which
the craft was moored as to make an easy flight for the mosquito bearing
DR. PRIDE JONES THOMAS,
WILMINGTON, N. G.
.2
the poison. The time occupied by one of the blockade runners between
Nassau and Wilmington was between three and four days. You will notice
also that the author of this article alludes to the rain fall during the
months of August, September and October; this atmospheric condition
making many collections of stagnant water in which mosquitoes might breed.
There was an outbreak of yellow fever in this town in 1854, but it oc-
curred so late in the fall that the appearance of an early frost put a
stop to the further progress of the disease. As far as I know, there
are no connective histories of previous outbreaks of this disease in
this community. It may interest you to know that Dr. John Guiteras,
now of Havana, whom you will recollect as the celebrated yellow fever
expert, entertained the opinion that many of the cases of so called
pernicious malarial fever, so aptly described in Woods' Practice, first
and second editions, were really cases of yellow fever in the cities
of the seaboard of the South Atlantic States.

I trust I have not trenched upon your time with so long a letter,
but you will easily understand my interest in this epidemic of 1862, in
which my grand-father bore so conspicuous a part.

I am sending you, under separate cover, a copy of the New York Medi-
cal Journal, above alluded to. If there is any other information I can
obtain for you regarding the outbreak of yellow fever in this community,
I shall be glad for you to indicate what information you desire, and it
will give me great pleasure to find it for you, if possible.

My father, Dr. Geo. G. Thomas, wishes to be remembered most kindly
to you, and joins me in my efforts to serve you.

As this Journal is one of my file, I would ask you please to return
it to me after it has served your purposes.
div1.closer: Yours very truly, Pride J Thomas.
